awd_titl_txt: Electrically-Induced Nonlinear Optical Processes in Plasmonic Metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Electrically-Induced Nonlinear Optical Processes in Plasmonic Metamaterials 
 
Non-Technical Description
This research project aims to explore the active control of nonlinear optical processes in photonic metamaterials using electrical means. Metamaterials are able to provide unorthodox properties not found in nature through ordered arrangements of artificially structured building blocks, and nonlinear optics is a critical branch of the science of light that facilitates the active manipulation of photons and the generation of new spectral components. The proposed research offers potentially transformative means to achieve dual electrical and optical functionalities for photonic applications by producing engineered photonic metamaterials with electrically enabled nonlinear optical effects. The research effort addresses fundamental questions about the laws of nonlinear optics, and meanwhile offers practical insights into how metamaterials can be utilized for electro-optic applications in both integrated photonics and liquid environments. Successful execution of this project will lead to a fundamentally new paradigm in the design and implementation of metamaterial-based optoelectronic systems for signal processing, biochemical sensing, and optical computing. This research is closely integrated with educational programs at the high school and collegiate levels, and is expected to enhance interdisciplinary thinking in future scientists and engineers through a rich set of educational and outreach activities. The research program will educate and interact with local K-12 school systems that are historically underrepresented, and highlight STEM related career pathways by facilitating interactive activities, demos and workshops with students.
 
Technical Description
The primary focus of this project is to harness the electrically-enabled nonlinear processes in plasmonic devices, and explore the use of metamaterials as self-sufficient electro-optic platforms for nonlinear signal generation, information processing, and optical sensing. Leveraging the optical and electrical functions simultaneously supported by nanostructured metals, this research comprehensively investigates electrically-enabled, nonlinear light-matter interactions that encompass material, component, and system levels. The goal of this project is to resolve the underdevelopment of photonic metamaterials in the electro-optic regime, and advance the state-of-the-art in the design and implementation of functional metamaterials. In this research, the investigator aims to unlock the full potential of plasmonic metamaterials for optoelectronic information technology by exploring metamaterials from an entirely distinct perspective. Instead of their conventional role as artificially structured materials with exotic optical properties, plasmonic metamaterials will be exploited to serve as a complete and generalizable electro-optic platform with intrinsically embedded electrical functions and optical nonlinearity. In particular, effective second-order nonlinear processes will be electrically enabled and actively controlled, thanks to the breaking of inversion symmetry induced by a low-frequency electric field or accumulation of electric charges. Central themes of the research include electrically-induced nonlinear optical generation in photonic metamaterials, and electrically-controlled nonlinear characterization with plasmonics in aqueous systems. The project addresses a grand challenge to push metamaterials beyond the scope of basic scientific research and towards real-world applications, which serve as a concrete step towards the national needs for seamless integration of photonics and electronics.

por.por_cntn:
Light represents the ultimate carrier of information, thanks to the enormous bandwidth and processing speed associated with optical waves. The active control of optical signals and the generation of new spectral components rely on the subject of nonlinear optics, an essential branch of optics science that describes the interaction of intensive light with certain media. Materials used in typical practice of nonlinear optics include specialized crystals and chemically synthesized polymers. There is a growing trend to explore beyond these conventional materials, and develop artificially structured optical structures with tailored nonlinear optical responses.

One important category of engineered optical media is plasmonic metamaterials, which are man-made structures with delicately-crafted, metallic building blocks of subwavelength size. Plasmonic metamaterials can exhibit very exotic properties that were not observed or even speculated about in the past. Nonlinear optical effects in metamaterials offer the possibility to actively tune the properties of optical metamaterials in a transient, reversible manner. Dynamic control of metamaterials also implies that the optical behavior of the structures can be sensitized to external stimuli, an aspect critically important to national needs in communication, energy, environmental monitoring, and national security.

We studied various types of metamaterials, and explored electrically-enabled nonlinear optical generation and signal detection in these media. Material systems we designed and implemented include silicon metasurfaces with Mie resonances, metallic gratings with dark plasmonic modes, electro-responsive chiral metastructures, hybrid plasmonic devices that enable hot-carrier transport, and more. These findings provide a generic route towards the dynamic control of second-order nonlinear processes, such as sum/difference frequency generation, optical rectification, and Pockels effect, in electrically active photonic metamaterials. In addition, we identified a method to utilize metallic structures as photodetection devices for the transduction of light to electrical signals. Through these numerical and experimental studies, we demonstrated a generalizable scheme to unlock the full potential of plasmonic metamaterials for optoelectronic information technology, by exploring metamaterials as self-sufficient electrooptic platforms via nonlinear light-matter interactions. The study offers potentially transformative means to achieve novel functionalities for photonic applications, including signal generation, electrooptic modulation, optical detection, wavefront control, beam steering, environmental sensing, and optical computing.

We also performed a systematic study of chiral metamaterials, which exhibit gigantic chiral-optical responses orders of magnitude stronger than their naturally occurring counterparts. Chirality is an intrinsic feature of certain molecules and structures, and is widely used as a powerful tool to identify compounds or measure concentrations in industrial and biological applications. We studied the linear and nonlinear optical responses of various chiral metamaterials, which features substantial circular dichroism and nonlinear optical behavior. In the linear regime, our chiral media strongly absorb a circularly polarized wave of one spin state and reflects or transmit that of the opposite spin in a manner conserving the circular polarization. Moreover, these artificially structured chiral media exhibit extraordinary strong nonlinear optical responses, in terms of chiral-selective signal generation and intensity-modulated optical rotation. Considering the pivotal role of chirality and optical spin in biochemistry and optics science, development of such man-made chiral media with externally modulated chiroptical properties is expected to shed new light on biochemical applications and photonic information processing.

By the end of the performance period, the project has produced 15 peer-reviewed publications in high profile journals such as Physical Review Letters, Advanced Materials, Nano Letters, Nature Communications, etc., with further papers in development. Numerous keynote, invited, and contributed presentations have been delivered by the PI and participating students at mainstream conferences.

This project offers a great opportunity for students in the PI's group to conduct state-of-the-art research in nanophotonics. The graduate students directly involved in this research got an excellent opportunity to receive additional training in experimental skills, numerical methods, academic policies, presentation prowess, etc. The research tasks and related activities in the project push the boundary of their knowledge base, and make them better scientists, researchers, and team workers for their academic career ahead. The students have been very successful toward their thesis research and future career goals, as indicated by the numerous honors and distinctions (e.g., SPIE D.J. Lovell Scholarship, Sigma Xi Best PhD Thesis Award, etc.) they have received during the course of the project. One student (Dr. Shoufeng Lan) is now an Assistant Professor at Texas A& M University.

The research is closely integrated with educational programs at the high school and collegiate levels. Through the outreach activities such as the "Day of Light" workshop, the Georgia Tech Tec Camp, the Regional Georgia Science Olympiad Tournament, the Grady High School Academic Fair, etc., this research program educated and interacted with local K-12 school systems, especially those historically underrepresented. Such activities not only provide the K-12 students a rare opportunity to be exposed to the exciting world of photonics, but also inspire and motivate them in pursuing higher degrees of education, specifically in science, engineering, and technology.
